discourse_list.title: stkMKR: Maker Staking and Tokenomics Revision

content.content: Introduction Maker faces frequent criticism of having weak token economics. This document lays out an alternative token economic mechanism that could supplement the current buyback value accrual system. The existing buy and burn mechanism has some key benefits, which stkMKR will try to preserve as much as possible:  Gas efficient - no transactions required to claim and reinvest dividends or other payouts Tax efficient - buybacks may have more favorable tax treatment vs cash dividends  At the same time, this staking system will try to address drawbacks of the existing system:  Lack of targeted incentives - token economics can incentivize positive behavior within a protocol, but buyback and burn returns capital to all MKR holders equally and doesn’t target incentives towards those token holders providing excess value Weak crypto narrative - buy and burn is out of favor and an update could stoke greater interest in the Maker protocol; while in my opinion tokenomics should not be focused on price impacts, positive narrative shifts benefit the protocol by making MKR issuance for hiring, capital raising, and user incentivization more efficient Limited deterrence against governance attacks - Currently it is possible for MKR owners to vote on a malicious proposal and then immediately withdraw funds and interact with defi protocols, which makes it nearly impossible to burn an attacker’s stake (they could be commingled with lending or AMM exchange pools and contaminate funds held by other users)   stkMKR Overview stkMKR token economics mechanism is primarily inspired by Cosmos style governance, with additional influence from stkAAVE and xSUSHI token economics. A new token, stkMKR, will replace MKR as the core governance token of MakerDAO. stkMKR will be non-transferable, and represents MKR staked in governance. Staked tokenholders will receive a share of MKR tokens purchased through surplus auctions, so stkMKR will be backed by an increasing amount of MKR over time (automatically compounding like xSUSHI). Withdrawing from stkMKR requires waiting through a pre-set unbonding period, which improves protocol resilience and governance security (similar to Cosmos and stkAAVE). The figures below offer a high level overview of the stkMKR mechanism.  1600×836 109 KB  Users can stake MKR in governance to receive stkMKR, representing their voting power and right to redeem a share of underlying MKR. stkMKR is held within voting contracts, and can be freely delegated/redelegated across registered voting contracts with no delay or unbonding period.  1600×1413 197 KB  A portion of MKR received through surplus auctions is diverted from burning to stkMKR holders. This could also be topped up manually by governance from the treasury or from new minting. MKR is drip fed into the pool over time to smooth out yield volatility and support countercyclical yield increases if a large share of staked MKR is withdrawn. Rewards gradually increase the ratio of MKR per stkMKR.  1600×830 113 KB  To withdraw funds, users must initiate withdrawal and then wait through a fixed unbonding period. During this time, stkMKR is burned and corresponding MKR is transferred to an escrow, where it will no longer earn yield or have voting rights. After the unbonding period elapses, users can claim liquid MKR tokens from the escrow. Any additional withdrawal requests from the same address will overwrite the escrow unlock date, prolonging the unbonding period for any partially unbonded MKR. Alternatively, users can immediately re-stake their MKR back into stkMKR at any point during the unbonding period (for example if they want to vote on an important proposal).  Motivation This token economic change is targeting the following improvements:  Incentivize governance participation: while the mechanism doesn’t directly incentivize voting or other actions, staking rewards may help improve participation and delegation rates. Improve value accrual narrative for MKR token: concrete APR figures and supply restriction may help improve market sentiment. Increase governance security: staking yield makes token lending less attractive, while unbonding periods may help deter governance attacks and make them more costly to execute. Unbonding also disincentivizes participation through centralized exchanges or other pooled staking services which could compromise MakerDAO decentralization. Increase resilience to credit losses: unbonding periods keeps a share of MKR tokens off the market during market crashes and recapitalization events. This prevents staked MKR holders from front-running debt auctions.   Components stkMKR Token stkMKR is a mintable token representing a share of MKR staked in governance. It is not generally transferable; it can only be minted into or transferred between voting or delegate contracts. This allows for full participation within governance, while ensuring that staked MKR cannot be traded on liquid markets. Surplus Auction Changes After surplus auctions purchase MKR, tokens are now sent to a splitter contract that routes a governance defined percent of tokens for burn, staking rewards, and any other approved uses. MKR allocated to staking rewards is deposited in a dripper contract. All MKR held within the contract vests to stakers linearly over a governance defined period. Whenever a new MKR deposit is made either through surplus auctions or governance action, this resets the vesting end date, reallocating remaining unvested MKR over the new vesting period. This will lead to relatively smooth changes in MKR staking yield. Governance System Changes Migration: Core governance, voting, and delegation contracts would be updated to support the stkMKR token. This likely requires a governance migration, which could cause user inconvenience and expense, and temporarily reduce governance security. Conditional delegation: Additionally, I propose to adjust the mechanism for evaluating governance poll (but not executive) vote outcomes to conform with the Cosmos framework of “conditional delegation”. When tallying poll results, delegates’ voting choices will be subordinated to any contrary votes submitted by delegators. So for example if I have 8,000 stkMKR voting power as a delegate and vote yes on a poll, but one of my delegators votes no and contributed 3,000 stkMKR voting power, the net result would be 5,000 yes and 3,000 no votes. This mechanism encourages continued governance engagement from delegators and may make owners more willing to delegate votes (as they retain greater sovereignty over their voting power if needed). Vote owners would still need to redelegate votes and/or vote on a cancellation if they strongly disagree with a delegate’s executive voting choice. Disaster recovery: In the event of a malicious governance attack or emergency shutdown, it is important to bifurcate staked (voting) vs unstaked (non voting) MKR to allow for a clean and orderly recovery of the Maker protocol. Otherwise, funds deposited in lending or AMM pools could be contaminated by MKR withdrawn by the attacker, and it will not be possible to cleanly burn an attacker’s stake. To accomplish this, I propose an additional governance controlled power to permanently lock all MKR currently staked in or unbonding from governance. If this is triggered via an executive vote, unbonding and withdrawal transactions will be permanently disabled (locking all staked or unbonding MKR in governance) - deposit/staking transactions will still be permitted to allow additional MKR owners to lock their tokens and participate in further governance votes. The protocol can then coordinate to redeploy a new MKR token. A migration contract will be provided for MKR tokens that are unstaked (ensuring funds held in defi protocols or centralized exchanges continue to hold value based on their ability to be converted to the new MKR token), and a merkle claim contract will be provided for staked MKR tokens (excluding tokens held by malicious parties). This enables MakerDAO to cleanly and verifiably burn attackers’ stake in the protocol without disruptive snapshot based migrations that risk total loss of funds held in AMM exchanges (owners of old MKR could dump into AMM after snapshot) or collateral damage to lending protocols (owners of old MKR could deposit to lending protocols and borrow funds after snapshot). If the permanent lock mechanism is triggered maliciously, it would cause some disruption but minimal long term damage to the protocol - MakerDAO would simply carry out the above recovery migration process and remove the attacker’s stake. Example Parameters stkMKR unbonding period: 21 days stkMKR surplus auction share: 30% (remaining 70% burned) Dripper linear vesting period: 90 days  Impact on MKR Token Payouts These changes will reduce the overall buyback yield attributable to all circulating MKR, while offering a new yield source specific to staked MKR. This should increase stkMKR effective yield at the expense of unstaked MKR. Demonstration with Example Values MKR market cap = $2 billion Maker annual profit = $100 million Annual MKR buyback = $50 million (remaining $50 million added to surplus buffer) Currently all MKR buybacks are burned, yielding a buyback yield of 2.5% in this example. Assuming 30% stkMKR surplus auction share from above, the new mechanism would distribute this as: Annual stkMKR rewards = $15 million Annual MKR burn = $35 million In this case, annual buyback yield is reduced to 1.75%, while staked MKR receives an additional yield source depending on the portion of MKR staked. At 100% of tokens staked, reward yield is 0.75%, and all MKR/stkMKR holders are earning the same 2.5% total yield. At 50% staked, reward yield is 1.5% for a total stkMKR yield of 3.25% (an increase of 0.75%). At 20% staked, reward yield is 3.75% for a total stkMKR yield of 5.5% (an increase of 3%). This is roughly equivalent to current participation rates within governance. From the example above we see that this payout distribution mechanism significantly increases returns for committed holders at any given rate of underlying profits.  Further Discussion I welcome any and all feedback on this proposed governance framework (mechanism design, technical implementation, etc)! Depending on community reception, I’ll continue to steward this through the governance process towards a full MIP and implementation.

content.content: Doo_StableLab:  I believe this model is deflationary model and what’s your thought on why it’s better than the inflationary model?   Mechanism should ideally be able to support both deflationary (funded through buyback) and inflationary (funded through governance token minting) staking rewards. Politically I think minting for staking rewards might be a tougher sell? But the staking rewards would be non-dilutive (at least for active participants) so maybe MKR holders would support inflationary staking rewards.     PhiMarHal:  Correct me if I’m wrong: wouldn’t it be possible to bypass this no transfer lock by wrapping the stkMKR token? i.e. with a custom contract you could transfer ownership of.   So one way to address this is via smart contract allowlisting (similar to Curve). I think this would be sub-optimal because (1) it interferes with owners who use contract wallets (argent, generic proxies, etc) or multisigs for personal or security reasons, and (2) it will soon be possible to bypass contract allowlists using MPC and other extra protocol mechanisms - eg. something like Sommelier, or even custodial solutions. I think a better approach is forming strong social consensus against tokenization of locked stkMKR. Then, if someone chooses to disregard this community standard, we can partially or fully burn their stake through the disaster recovery / migration mechanism outlined above (lock all stkMKR, issue new token with deposit based migration for unstaked MKR and merkle claim for staked MKR, and partially or fully remove offending tokens from merkle claim).

content.content: sambacha:  Why should MakerDAO as a whole subsidize this new risk for the benefit of stkMKR?   The way I see it, beneficiaries are the Maker protocol and DAI system users (who benefit from greater protection from and deterrence against government attacks), and the party(s) at risk are stkMKR holders (who may have their tokens unexpectedly locked within governance if the recovery mechanism is triggered). So it is more like stkMKR holders subsidizing governance risk on behalf of protocol and users. This is compensated for by diverting a portion of Maker protocol profits from burn to staking rewards.     sambacha:  This token migration fiction will be exceedingly hard to coordinate, and is bar far the most tenuous portion of this proposal.   I think you’re right that the recovery process would be disruptive, but we can help reduce negative impacts by (1) making a thorough process MIP explaining why the mechanism would typically be triggered, what sort of actions would qualify for burning/slashing stake and how much, sequential steps involved in carrying out migration/recovery process, and (2) pre-built technical components for the new MKR token, deposit migration contract for unstaked MKR, and merkle claim contract for staked MKR tokens. If we have a playbook for these situations, it will make our deterrence more credible and will also reduce coordination costs of recovery.

content.content: The ultimate deterrence against governance attacks is reducing the surface area applicable to governance (i.e. reduction in what is controlled directly by governance). This proposal increases the surface area, so I can’t necessarily agree with the point that “(sic)…party(s) at risk are stkMKR holders”. Why stake when you can lend? Why not offer some DAI in exchange for MKR deposits? Some portion can be consumed in the process (being deposited back to Treasury for example). DAI on-lend would be minted by Maker itself. Total lent out would be capped globally by a set %. The consumed MKR would have to be greater than the cost of minting DAI via CDP (the transactional costs). Or make this an option of new CDPs, as a way for people to farm governance votes. People interested in Maker Governance would have a market in which they could capture peoples MKR votes. You would also then have the ability to compare performance of said delegated MKR voters over time. IDK YMMV, would like to see more info on the rewards payout etc.

content.content: sambacha:  The ultimate deterrence against governance attacks is reducing the surface area applicable to governance (i.e. reduction in what is controlled directly by governance). This proposal increases the surface area, so I can’t necessarily agree with the point that “(sic)…party(s) at risk are stkMKR holders”.   I agree with this goal (minimizing governance over time), but imo this proposal doesn’t really expand the effective scope of governance from where it stands today. It just makes voters have more accountability for their choices (they can’t atomically withdraw and dump their tokens after passing a proposal).     sambacha:  Why stake when you can lend? Why not offer some DAI in exchange for MKR deposits? Some portion can be consumed in the process (being deposited back to Treasury for example). DAI on-lend would be minted by Maker itself. Total lent out would be capped globally by a set %. The consumed MKR would have to be greater than the cost of minting DAI via CDP (the transactional costs).   I think this proposal benefits the protocol by reducing lending/collateralization activity for MKR. My reasoning:   Reducing the amount of borrowable MKR tokens: This is good because MKR borrowers have no price exposure to MKR so can’t be relied upon to have incentive alignment with respect to their votes/actions in governance.  Reducing the amount of money lent against MKR collateral: This is also good because (1) leverage against MKR tokens can lead to forced selling during recapitalization events, which exhausts limited liquidity resources we rely upon to cover bad debt with flop auctions, and (2) these users who collateralize loans with MKR have arguably lower incentive alignment with MakerDAO (they have basically bought a sort of conditional put option on MKR, with strike price at their liquidation price and premium equal to their liquidation penalty, so their max losses are capped vs regular MKR holders). If MKR is used as primary DAI collateral (first line of defense), this reduces effectiveness of MKR as a recapitalization resources (last line of defense).  I also tend to think ability to borrow protocol minted DAI against MKR is a very weak incentive to hold MKR (even if we charge 0%, there is little excess value vs just using Compound or Aave). And this mechanism has really high returns to scale - for someone like myself with 5 figure MKR exposure, I just don’t have enough scale to make collateralized borrowing worthwhile on L1, and I assume many other engaged governance participants are in the same boat. Only whales would be able to benefit from a “supply MKR borrow DAI” mechanism.     sambacha:  Or make this an option of new CDPs, as a way for people to farm governance votes. People interested in Maker Governance would have a market in which they could capture peoples MKR votes.   Generally don’t think vote renting/buying is incentive aligned. So I think this sort of activity is something to be discouraged rather than encouraged.

content.content: Thanks for this post @monet-supply  brings me back to my earlier days of contributing with MIP49: Staking Rewards. Think there’s a lot of good discussion points here and don’t wanna derail the conversation, but one concern I haven’t seen expressed yet is the implications of this idea on Emergency Shutdown. You mention ES related to a governance attack, but one concern I have from this proposed structure is that activating the ESM would become very difficult due to the unlock delay. In theory the ESM is our big red button that we could push during an attack if it seems we’re unable to pass a canceling motion through governance within the 48 hour delay. I suspect stakers would be primarily active DAO contributors/MKR investors, or the exact group of people we’d want to contact if the need for an Emergency Shutdown arose. Since (if successful) it would be rational to stake your MKR and you would miss out on profits by not doing so, anyone paying close enough attention would be time delayed from assisting with an ESM activation. All that is to say I think if implemented we’d need to seriously reconsider the feasibility of the ESM. This is not a non-starter as some have already been questioning the functionality of the mechanism, but should probably be considered as an additional technical labor requirement for this proposal idea.

content.content: Generally, I like the proposal. It should do a much better job at increasing MKR price (turning MKR into a productive asset, taking MKR off the market). Finally, it fixes serious governance attack vectors (voting on a proposal and dumping MKR later). I really like that stkMKR appreciates in value rather than “grows in amount” b/c that should be simpler in terms of tax (cTokens vs aTokens). Have you thought about “reward tiers” ie. lock MKR for longer, receive more rewards? That being said, I am strongly against fixing tokeneconomics now. MakerDAO faces a serious problem of DAI supply crisis. A lot of DAI is created via USDC, we are having issues with finding good ways of extending our credit line. As I wrote multiple times before, I believe we should stop burn entirely and refocus on growth by growing surplus buffer. This proposal touches multiple parts of the system and will require serious engineering efforts. We can spend months working on this, only not to realize that we have no revenue to funnel it to.

content.content: I think this proposal contains all of the elements that we’d like to see as part of a tokenomics rework from a governance facilitation point of view. We’ve mentioned before that we consider the key elements to any on-chain governance incentives be:  Rewards are available for both delegation and direct voting. Rewards are linked to the performance of the protocol. Rewards encourage longer-term thinking.  This proposal hits #1, #2 and to a limited extent #3, and I think it does it in a way that preserves the benefits of the current MKR tokenomics. There is an argument for preventing MKR being manually added to rewards, on the grounds that MKR Holders can vote themselves more tokens regardless of how well the protocol is doing… But in practice if governance gets to that stage, there is not much we can do to prevent looting of value from the protocol. On balance it probably makes sense to have the option available. Conditional delegation is a nice touch that hasn’t been high on our list, but does provide some benefit. I’m not 100% sure that we need to wholesale replace MKR as the governance token, I suspect much or possibly all of this is doable using the current IOU token that the governance contract emits. (ie stkMKR is actually stkIOU under the hood.) Is this something you’d considered and dismissed? Payton makes a good point about Emergency Shutdown as well. I think in some proposal I’d read, there was an idea of allowing faster-unlock, but applying a semi-significant fee. This might let users exit to trigger shutdown in an emergency, while still binding voters to the consequences of their vote.

content.content: joey:  Interesting proposal! If this does get implemented, stkMKR should be transferrable and compatible with ERC-4626 if possible. What is the logic for non-transferrable?   Making the token transferable and compatible with yield strategy interfaces can potentially introduce unintended economic incentives - eg. borrowing against governance tokens provides a similar payoff to buying a put option.  It also removes the safety benefits of unbonding period - as stkMKR is integrated across defi, it would no longer be possible to hold malicious owners accountable for their actions as they could commingle funds with lending or AMM pools. So from my perspective I think it’s better to maintain non-transferability. (I am very hyped about the potential of ERC-4626 in other domains though!)     Sandwalker:  Does the staking have a time weighted and decaying features?   Staking wouldn’t have time weighting or decaying features (eg. all stakers would accrue rewards at the same APY, and would remain fully bonded until they request withdrawal/unbonding). I think this is an important difference to veToken type mechanism, where the need to frequently submit transactions to re-lock your decaying gov token stake makes it prohibitively expensive to participate for small token holders. The linear vesting above refers to issuance of rewards to the staking pool, and is intended to smooth out yield volatility (MKR buybacks from surplus auctions can be very volatile, particularly if Maker earns revenue from liquidation auctions, and it seems preferable to have staking returns be less volatile and event driven).     jurajpetrik:  From the perspective of someone who treats MKR as a stock and just wants to hold it forever Jack Bogle style you’ve maintained all the benefits and removed a systemic weakness.   Thanks for your comment, this was 100% what I was shooting for! I hope this token economics mechanism is suitable for people with small to medium size positions who want to hold and accumulate MKR over the long term while supporting sound governance through delegation.     makercaesar:  You may then have to guarantee that there will be this specific distribution for year X, this would lead to further undesirable side effects, the behaviour of the voters would then tend to pay out more and more, guarantees for profit distribution are difficult to implement and it is also another risk.       makercaesar:  I just would like to have no distribution if there is nothing to distribute, by this I mean that MKR should be distributed with added value generated by the protocol itself, and not simply mint to increase the supply, if the protocol is not net profit.   I understand the concern, but don’t really think this would cause problems in practice. Staking rewards would be non-dilutive (at least for those MKR holders who are staking). While there may be some incentives for staked voters to increase rewards rates arbitrarily, I trust the DAO would be able to find the right balance - issuing too high of inflationary staking rewards would penalize liquidity provision and likely lead to reduced price support, so it wouldn’t be in anyone’s interest to pursue this beyond a certain point. I get the sense that most MKR holders are not actively trading their positions or expecting immediate liquidity, so would be willing to accept a 2-3 week unbonding period even without any staking payouts (during periods when the protocol is not net profitable or when the surplus buffer has not been filled). And a very small inflationary reward (1-2% apy) would probably be enough to incentivize deposits if we find that governance has insufficient tokens staked to maintain adequate security.     McGanja:  This is all a bit over my head. I have gathered and held a small amount of maker and kept it in my private wallet for a few years now. I dont have the time or confidence to vote on things but I wanted to work towards knowing more. Is there a way you can summarize how this will affect a MKR holder like me in the next 12 months?   I think this sort of token economics should serve owners like yourself well. You could earn a slightly higher rate of return when the protocol is profitable (a portion of MKR buybacks would be granted to locked stakers rather than distributed to all MKR holders through burn) as long as you don’t mind waiting for a few weeks to withdraw your tokens when you wish to sell (but if you’ve already been holding for years this is probably not a big concern for you). Like the current voting system, you can also choose a delegate to vote on your behalf, so your tokens will be engaged in governance without requiring you to participate on each vote directly. And the “conditional delegation” feature for polls would still give you the option to overwrite your delegate’s poll votes if there’s something you feel strongly about, so you can increase your direct engagement with governance over time. Also think this will improve governance security, so there is less “black swan” risk of someone staging a governance attack that negatively impacts the protocol.     krzkaczor:  Have you thought about “reward tiers” ie. lock MKR for longer, receive more rewards?   This could be interesting (eg lock for 3 weeks for 1x reward, 3 months for 2x reward), but also seems like it would significantly increase complexity and I’m not certain how much benefit this would bring to incentive alignment or price support.     krzkaczor:  That being said, I am strongly against fixing tokeneconomics now. MakerDAO faces a serious problem of DAI supply crisis. A lot of DAI is created via USDC, we are having issues with finding good ways of extending our credit line. As I wrote  multiple times before , I believe we should stop burn entirely and refocus on growth by growing surplus buffer. This proposal touches multiple parts of the system and will require serious engineering efforts. We can spend months working on this, only not to realize that we have no revenue to funnel it to.   I completely understand this perspective, and agree that tokenomics should never be the top priority unless it clearly helps achieve more tangible goals. As a counterpoint, if we pursue the aggressive growth strategy by raising large amounts of capital through MKR sales, creating a supply sink/locking mechanism for MKR might provide price support and help us get more bang for our buck (build up more DAI surplus per issued MKR).     LongForWisdom:  There is an argument for preventing MKR being manually added to rewards, on the grounds that MKR Holders can vote themselves more tokens regardless of how well the protocol is doing… But in practice if governance gets to that stage, there is not much we can do to prevent looting of value from the protocol. On balance it probably makes sense to have the option available.   Rewards are non-dillutive and would accrue to all engaged owners equally, so other than potential negative impacts on MKR liquidity on centralized or decentralized exchanges (which would not be earning these rewards), narrative violation (many MKR investors are very aligned with deflationary supply meme), and a few corner cases (eg. if we inflate supply a really huge amount we might need to reduce opening price for debt/flop auctions), I don’t see this as a problem. Engaged owners who stake would see their share of ownership stay the same or increase, but never decline due to staking rewards. I trust voters to not shoot themselves in the foot by nuking MKR liquidity and rekting our primary value accrual narrative      Spidomo:  Add a function which withdraws stkMKR with no unlock delay directly into the Emergency Shutdown Module?   I think we should preserve emergency shutdown mechanism, and something like this would probably be the most suitable option.     Ber10:  Is this going to cause new MKR to be issued for the people involved in governance ? So MKR would become inflationary ? If that is the case I dont see how we wont lose on the Eth-MKR ratio in the long term.   IMO doesn’t really matter, ownership interest would be more correlated with stkMKR/ETH ratio (value of MKR you can withdraw from staking, which would increase in tandem with any inflationary rewards governance chooses to issue).
